did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Includes materials relating to Knight Biggerstaff's career as a scholar of Chinese history, including extensive records of travel in the Far East, and to his term as chair of the History Department at Cornell University.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Professor of Chinese History, 1927-1978; Chairman, Department of Far Eastern Studies, Cornell University, 1946-1956; Chairman, History Department, Cornell University, 1956-1965.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Includes administrative correspondence of both departments and correspondence, memoranda, minutes, reports, notes, and other items concerning his participation in the American Council of Learned Societies and its Committee on Far Eastern Studies, American Historical Association, Association for Asian Studies, and Institute of Pacific Relations, of which he was a trustee of the American branch; some of the IPR records relate to the McCarran Subcommittee investigation of that organization. Professor Biggerstaff's handwritten notes (1927-1933) from Harvard University classes and lecture notes for his own Cornell classes and for the Army Special Training Program at Cornell (1944), all relating to the Far East. Also, letters to Biggerstaff and drafts of some of Biggerstaff's outgoing correspondence with fellow China scholars, students and personal friends; letters of recommendation for former students and colleagues; documentation of Biggerstaff's travel and study abroad (China and Europe); reviews of colleagues' books for historical publications; and material describing his security hearings in 1954 including Biggerstaff's statement in defense of his own loyalty as well as statements for many colleagues (c.1954). Frequent correspondents include China scholars such as: George H. Blakeslee, O. Edmund Clubb, John K. Fairbank, George McTuran Kahin, and Ssu-yü Teng.

Also, letters, 1961-1991, from Dr. Biggerstaff to Dr. Arun K. Dasgupta, a graduate student of his who returned to Calcutta, India and also taught in Jakarta, Indonesia. Includes personal, family, and professional news; also, Biggerstaff's letters from China (1945-49) and Camilla Biggerstaff's letters from China (1923-31).

These papers include correspondence to the Biggerstaff and drafts of some of Biggerstaff's outgoing correspondence with fellow China scholars, students, and personal friends; letters of recommendation for former students and colleagues; documentation of Biggerstaff's travel and study abroad (china and Europe); reviews of colleagues' books for historical publications; and material describing his security hearings in 1954 including Biggerstaff's statement in defense of correspondents include China scholars such as: George H. Blakeslee, O. Edmund Clubb, John K. Fairbank, George McT. Kahin, and Ssu-yu Teng.

Material is arranged alphabetically within 2 or 3 year periods, as Professor Biggerstaff left the papers. These periods often correspond roughly to inclusive dates. Series indicate original groupings of material by box. Althouhg the material remains in the same overall order as Professor Biggerstaff arranged it, some groups of material were consolidated or divided into different folders to facilitate storage. The alphabetical order is not always apparent but has been maintained wherever possible.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Knight Biggerstaff papers, #14-17-629. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

defitem.label: Series II. 1928-1931, First three years in China (living in Peking), first year at the North China Union Language School learning Chinese, next two years at Yenching University (on a Harvard-Yenching Institute fellowship) pursuing graduate studies in Chinese history; travel in other parts of China, briefly in Korea
Series III. 1931-1934, Graduate study at Harvard, completing Ph.D.
Series IV. 1934-1936, Post-doctoral study in Peking on Social Science Research Council fellowship; published An Annotated Bibliography of Selected Chinese Reference Works with S.Y. Teng
Series V. 1936-1938, Instructor in Chinese history and language at the University of Washington
Series VI. 1938-1940, First two years at Cornell as Assistant Professor of Chinese History

Series VII. 1940-1942, At Cornell, including 1942 Summer Workshop on Far East, British Commonwealth and Latin America and 1941 American Council of Learned Societies, Chinese and Japanese Language Courses
Series VIII. 1938-1940, Records as Secretary of Committee on Chinese Studies of the American Council of Learned Societies
Series IX. 1940-1941, Records as Secretary of Committee on Chinese Studies of the American Council of Learned Societies

Series X. 1942-1944, War Years at Cornell, including material of Committee on Asiatic Studies of ACLS. All material on the Chinese Army Specialized Training Program Biggerstaff directed is filed with other ASTP records in University Archives
Series XI. 1944-1946, Six months in Division of Territorial Studies, U.S. Dept. of State and one year as Chinese Secretary of U.S. Embassy Chungking
Series XII. 1946-1947, From June 1946, return to Cornell; most correspondence as Chairman of Department of Chinese (later, Far Eastern and still later, Asian) Studies is in that department's files

Series XIII. 1947-1949, Includes material regarding an American Historical Association Program Committee, the Committee on Asiatic Studies of the American Council on Education, the San Diego American Institute of Pacific Relations Conference and a research trip to Nanking, China; correspondence relating to ACLS Committee on Far Eastern Studies mainly in ACLS files
Series XIV. 1949-1951, Back at Cornell; includes material on Nanking trip with unedited copy of diary letters
Series XV. 1951-1955, Miscellaneous correspondence, including David Rowe attack

Series XVI. 1954, Security hearing to appeal denial of security clearance by Eastern Industrial Personnel Security Board for work with Operations Research Office, a research agency for Johns Hopkins University
Series XVII. 1954, Security hearing documents
Series XVIII. 1955-1957, Cornell Department of History, related material for chairmanship (1956-1964) in that department's files
Series XIX. 1957-1960, Miscellaneous correspondence
Series XX. 1960-1963, Miscellaneous correspondence
Series XXI. 1963-1965, Includes 1963 sabbatical trip to Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Indonesia, and Europe
Series XXII. 1965-1968, Includes Wells College Long-Range Planning Committee; correspondence as President of the Association for Asian Studies sent to Association headquarters in Ann Arbor
Series XXIII. 1968-1972, Miscellaneous correspondence up to time of retirement
Series XXIV. 1972-1978, Post-retirement correspondence

Series II. First three years in China (living in Peking), first year at the North China Union Language School learning Chinese, next two years at Yenching University (on a Harvard-Yenching Institute fellowship) pursuing graduate studies in Chinese history; travel in other parts of China, briefly in Korea
Correspondence (A): Manchurian Trip June 13-July 16, 1929; Shantung Trip January 1931 ; Shanghai-Shensi Trip May 1930 .

Correspondence (B): Yangtse Valley Trip April-May 1931 ; family correspondence 1928-1931 . [It appears the correspondence about these trips was a sort of journal kept for documentation of graduate work and study.]
Chinese Study (C): 1929-1930 documents Biggerstaff's fellowship at Yenching University and University and University of Nanking Institute of Chinese Cultural Studies.
Series III. 1931-1934, Graduate study at Harvard, completing Ph.D.
Correspondence (T-Z): 1931-1933 Biggerstaff's review of The Mind of China by Edwin Harvey.
Manuscripts: 1934 and n.d. includes Chinese lottery ticket, Chinese menu, and program from Harvard Commencement (PhD)
Series IV. 1934-1936, Post-doctoral study in Peking on Social Science Research Council fellowship. Published An Annotated Bibliography of Selected Chinese Reference Works with S. Y. Teng
Correspondence (A): 1936 concerning American Historical Review and American Council of Learned Societies.
Correspondence (S): 1934-1936 includes Social Science Research Council
Correspondence (S): 1933-1936 includes Social Science Research Council
Correspondence (W-Z): 1935-1936 includes manuscripts: "American Students in China," "The Official Chinese Attitude toward the Burlingame Mission," and notes for speech.
Series V. 1936-1938, Instructor in Chinese history and language at the University of Washington
Memorabilia and manuscript (A): 1933-1935 , n.d. includes manuscript "Yenching and its Possibilities".
Correspondence (A-B): 1936-1938 includes program for Fifteenth Session of the Institute of World Affairs, 1937 .
Correspondence (P): 1936-1938 includes manuscript "The First Chinese Mission of Investigation Sent to Europe"
Correspondence (W-Z): 1936-1938 includes resignation from University of Washington.
Correspondence: 1937 , 1938 Camilla to Knight; Clipping: 1929 ; Lease for apartment in Seattle
Series VI. 1938-1940, First two years at Cornell as Assistant professor of Chinese History
Correspondence: 1938 concerns original appointment as assistant professor of Chinese history
Correspondence (C): 1938-1940 includes clippings about development of Far Eastern Studies at Cornell
Correspondence (P-Q): 1938-1940 includes death of Dr. Robert T. Pollard
Manuscripts and notes: "Some Notes on the Tung-hua Lu and the Shih-lu"
Manuscripts and notes: annotated version of "Some Notes on the Tung-hua Lu and the Shih-lu"

Series VII. 1940-1942, At Cornell, including 1942 Summer Workshop on Far East, British Commonwealth and Latin America and 1941 American Council of Learned Societies Chinese and Japanese Language Courses.
Correspondence: 1942 concerns 1942 Workshop on Latin America, the Far East, and the British Commonwealth
Correspondence (A-B): 1940-1942 includes manuscript "Archaeological Researches in China 1923-1924 "
Manuscripts: 1939 , n.d. "The Chinese Joint-Family: Its Role and Recent Trends," "A Reappraisal of the Far Eastern Policy of the United States"
Manuscripts: 1939-1942 "Anson Burlingame's Instructions from the Chinese Foreign Office," "The 'Right of Rebellion' in China"
Book Orders 1936-1941 checks, receipts, correspondence and orders
Series VIII. 1938-1940, Records as Secretary of Committee on Chinese Studies of the American Council of Learned Societies.
New York Meeting: 1940 Annual Meeting of the Committee on Chinese and Japanese Studies of the American Council of Learned Societies October 1940
ACLS Committee on Chinese Studies report on activities, 1940
Correspondence, Minutes: 1940 executive committee of American Council of Learned Societies meeting minutes, resumes of applicants for grants
Y. R. Chao: 1940 correspondence describes Chao's studies, includes manuscript "Proposals for Study of 'General Chinese'" by G. A. Kennedy of Yale
Correspondence: 1939 concerns Index to Oriental Art proposed by Helen E. Fernald
1940 Institute describes arrangement for Far Eastern Institute sponsored by Harvard Summer School, Harvard- Yenching Institute and American Council of Learned Societies
Correspondence regarding Committee on Chinese Studies of the American Council of Learned Societies, February 1937 -September 1939 , much concerns fellowship applications.
Series IX. 1940-1941, Records as Secretary of Committee on Chinese Studies of the American Council of Learned Societies
Annual Committee Meeting: October 1941 reports, minutes, and correspondence
Correspondence: 1941 includes ACLS and Far Eastern Quarterly
1941 Language Institute correspondence, announcements, financial records, and reports describe the 1941 Chinese and Japanese Language Institute at Cornell sponsored by ACLS and Cornell Summer Session
1941 Language Institute correspondence, announcements, financial records, and reports describe the 1941 Chinese and Japanese Language Institute at Cornell sponsored by ACLS and Cornell Summer Session

Series X. 1942-1944, War years at Cornell, including material on Committee on Asiatic Studies of ACLS. All material on the Chinese Army Specialized Training Program Biggerstaff directed is filed with other ASTP records in University Archives.
Correspondence (A): 1942-1944 includes development of curricula for teaching about Far East for Committee on Asiatic Studies in American Education
Correspondence (A): 1942-1943 Committee on Asiatic Studies in American Education, includes reports
Correspondence, reports (A): 1942-1944 Committee on Asiatic Studies in American Education
Correspondence (M-R): 1943-1944 includes armed services' attempts to recruit Biggerstaff for service in China
Manuscript (W): "The Westward Migration of the Chinese" includes notes and cover letter indicating publications to which it was submitted
Notes and correspondence: 1937-1939 , 1944 includes biographical sketches of famous Chinese people
Correspondence: 1936-1940 includes notes on "The Place of the Far East in the General History Curriculum"
Series XI. 1944-1946, Six months in Division of Territorial Studies, U.S. Dept. of State and one year as Chinese Secretary of U.S. Embassy Chungking.
Passports of Biggerstaff and wife, Camilla, includes copy of telegram
Correspondence (A): 1944-1946 includes manuscript "The Value of Far Eastern Area Studies for Civilian Undergraduates and Specialists"

Correspondence (B-C): 1938-1946 includes correspondence with Cornell U. Press regarding Biggerstaff's publication of China: Revolutionary Changes in an Ancient Civilization and regarding Biggerstaff's status on Cornell faculty
Correspondence (D-G): 1944-1946 includes Biggerstaff's appointment as Attache in the American Foreign Service Auxiliary
Correspondence (T-Z): 1944-1946 includes outline for possible book
Series XII. 1946-1947, From June 1946, return to Cornell. Most correspondence as Chairman of Department of Chinese (later, Far Eastern and still later, Asian) Studies is in that department's files.
Correspondence and Book Review: 1946-1947 include description of Biggerstaff's various faculty appointments at Cornell
Correspondence (K-Q): 1946-1947 includes material on celebration of Princeton Bicentennial

Series XIII. 1947-1949, Includes material regarding an American Historical Association Program Committee, the Committee on Asiatic Studies of the American Council on Education, the San Diego American Institute of Pacific Relations Conference and a research trip to Nanking, China. Correspondence relating to ACLS Committee on Far Eastern Studies mainly in ACLS files.
Correspondence: 1947-1948 includes research and publication plans
Correspondence: 1947-1948 includes Committee on Documentary Reproduction of the American Historical Association and Committee on International Education of American Council on Education
Book Reviews, Speeches: 1944 , 1946-1947 , 1949 includes Biggerstaff's draft card and a card in Chinese
Correspondence (E-F): 1948-1949 includes applications for grants to study in China
Correspondence (K-M): 1947-1949 includes substantial correspondence with and concerning John MacDonald
Correspondence (S): 1947-1949 includes conference on The Far East and the United States sponsored by The Maxwell Graduate School of Citizenship and Public Affairs (Syracuse U.)
Series XIV. 1949-1951, Back at Cornell, includes material on Nanking trip with unedited copy of diary letters.
Travel Documents, correspondence: 1949-1951 includes correspondence at time of Biggerstaff's mother's death
Biggerstaff Diary Letter from Nanking: April 23- July 30, 1949
Correspondence (D,E-F): 1949-1951 includes support of Owen Lattimore against McCarthy accusations
Correspondence (E-F): 1950-1951 includes Conference Board of Associated Research Councils, Committee on International Exchange of Persons
Correspondence (S): 1950 includes work with State Dept. Division of Research on Far East
Correspondence (W): 1950-1951 includes manuscript by Alien S. Whiting "The Soviet Offer to China of 1919 "
Correspondence (W): 1947-1951 includes extensive personal correspondence with J. B. Wood Realty Co.
Correspondence 1949-1951 includes manuscript "The Nanking Press, April to September 1949 "
Series XV. 1951-1955, Miscellaneous correspondence, including David Rowe attack.
"Rowe Row", Spring 1952 " clippings concern accusations made by David Rowe that Biggerstaff was a Communist sympathizer
Correspondence (G): 1950-1955 includes notes on plan for Chinese Research Program
Correspondence (H-J): 1951-1955 . includes: work with Harvard Committee for appointments in Departments of History and Government
Correspondence (M): 1952-1955 includes proposed National Council on Asian affairs
Correspondence, Manuscript (Y-Z): 1953-1955 , n.d. includes rough draft of manuscript on Chinese Communists

Series XVI. 1954, Security hearing to appeal denial of security clearance by Eastern Industrial Personnel Security Board for work with Operations Research Office, a research agency for Johns Hopkins University
Correspondence: 1954-1956 includes Leon Lipsoji, Biggerstaff's counsel for hearing
Correspondence: 1951 , 1954-1955 includes Johns Hopkins University Operations Research Office
Activities, Questions; 1954 table of Biggerstaff's activities and people with whom he associated during each period of his life, sample questions and answers for witnesses at security hearing
Appendix A of Personal Statement: 1954 "Development Of My Attitude Toward Events In The Far East, 1928-1954 "
Correspondence, affidavits: 1954 includes requests for, and later, acknowledgements of, affidavits by friends supporting Biggerstaff's loyalty
Notes: 1954 includes notes on people who wrote affidavits
Clippings, Notes: c. 1946-1950 describe Biggerstaff's assessment of Communist China
Transcript: "Hearing of Dr. Eugene Knight Biggerstaff" 1954 before Eastern Industrial Personnel Security Board
Manuscripts "Material Submitted to the Eastern Industrial Security Board Appeal Division on behalf of Knight Biggerstaff" 1954
Series XVIII. 1955-1957, Cornell department of history, related material for chairmanship (1956-1964) in that department's files.
Overseers' Committee to Visit the Department of History, Harvard: 1957-1963 documents Biggerstaff's work as advisor to history dept.
Correspondence (K-L): 1960-1963 includes manuscript by Donald Lach
Series XXI. 1963-1965, Includes 1963 sabbatical trip to Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Indonesia and Europe.
Series XXII. 1965-1968, Includes Wells College Long Range Planning Committee. Correspondence as President of the Association for Asian Studies sent to Association headquarters in Ann Arbor.
Correspondence (Y-Z): 1965-1967 includes manuscripts on non-proliferstion of atomic weapons
Series XXIII. 1968-1972, Miscellaneous correspondence up to time of retirement.
Correspondence (Y-Z): 1958-1959 , 1969-1971 includes activity against Vietnam War and receipts in Italian and Chinese
Correspondence (N-O): 1970-1971 , 1976 includes manuscript on proposed master's degree program in Asian Studies at SUNY New Paltz C1971)
